en_results_raw: and the men's forced merriment only served to heighten the sense of unease that settled over the gathering like a shroud. The woman's presence was a stark reminder that their carefully constructed facade was fragile, that the secrets they kept hidden could be exposed at any moment. As the night wore on, the tension grew thicker, until it seemed to vibrate through every molecule of air, threatening to shatter the delicate balance of their charade. The men's laughter began to sound hollow, their jokes falling flat, as they struggled to maintain the illusion of normalcy in the face of her unyielding silence. And yet, despite the growing unease, no one dared to confront her, to ask the questions that hung in the air like a challenge. Instead, they averted their eyes, pretending not to notice the way she seemed to be watching them, her gaze piercing the veil of their deception. The ritual, once a comforting routine, had been transformed into a twisted game of cat and mouse, with the woman as the unpredictable wild card. As the hours ticked by, the men's anxiety reached a fever pitch, until it seemed that the very walls were closing in on them, suffocating them with the weight of their own guilt.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.

Búsquelo en la vida misma, en su propia vida, en su propia alma. Porque allí es donde se encuentra la verdadera magia, la verdadera poesía, la verdadera música. No en los libros, no en las pantallas, no en las máquinas, sino en la experiencia humana, en la conexión con los demás, en la conexión con el mundo que nos rodea. Eso es lo que usted está buscando, amigo mío. Eso es lo que todos estamos buscando.

en_results_raw: and scattered, the books that had been the cause of all this chaos, their pages fluttering like wounded birds, their words, once full of meaning, now nothing more than scattered, meaningless scraps of paper. The room was heavy with the scent of smoke and ash, the acrid smell of destruction, and Montag's heart felt heavy with the weight of what he had done. He thought of Mildred, of her empty, vapid face, of her love of the parlour walls and the endless, mindless chatter of the seashell radios, and he felt a pang of sorrow, of regret for what he had lost, for what he had destroyed. He thought of Faber, of his wise, old eyes, of his gentle, guiding hand, and he felt a sense of gratitude, of hope. And he thought of the books, of their words, of their wisdom, and he knew that he had to keep them alive, to preserve them, to pass them on to a world that desperately needed them. He took a deep breath, and began to gather up the scattered pages, to collect the torn covers, to rebuild, to restart, to rediscover the knowledge, the wisdom, the beauty that had been lost.

La multitud que se había reunido para presenciar el espectáculo comenzó a dispersarse, murmurando y gesticulando entre sí. Montag se puso de pie, tambaleándose ligeramente, y se dirigió hacia la figura que se acercaba a él con una expresión de preocupación en el rostro. Era su compañero de trabajo, el capitán Beatty, quien le ayudó a enderezarse y le preguntó si se encontraba bien. Montag asintió, aún aturdido, y Beatty le dijo que había tenido suerte de escapar por tan poco. Mientras se alejaban del lugar del incidente, Montag no podía dejar de pensar en la extraña sensación que había experimentado al ver el vehículo que se acercaba a él a toda velocidad, y en la inexplicable sensación de alivio que había sentido al verlo desviarse en el último momento.

en_results_raw: drumbeat that was both soothing and terrifying. The sound followed him as he sprinted across the lawn, the droplets hitting his face like a thousand tiny fingers, each one reminding him of the life he was leaving behind. The night air was cool and damp, filled with the scent of wet earth and ozone, and Montag felt it fill his lungs as he ran. He didn't dare look back, fearing what he might see - the house, the lawn, the entire world he knew, all being washed away by the relentless rain. His heart pounded in his chest, and his legs pumped furiously as he devoured the distance, the valise bouncing against his leg. The rain intensified, drumming against his skin, and Montag felt his senses come alive, as if the storm was awakening a part of him that had long been dormant. He burst through the hedge and onto the sidewalk, the rain-soaked world stretching out before him like an endless, dark canvas, waiting to be explored.

Pero sabía que no era un sueño. Sabía que era la realidad, y que nada volvería a ser igual. Los reactores habían dejado de rugir, y el silencio era total. Montag se sintió como si estuviera en un vacío, un vacío que se extendía hasta el infinito. No sabía qué hacer, no sabía qué decir. Solo sabía que tenía que hacer algo, tenía que decir algo. Pero ¿qué? ¿Qué se podía decir en un momento como ese? ¿Qué se podía hacer en un momento como ese? Montag se sintió como si estuviera paralizado, como si estuviera atrapado en un momento del tiempo que no podía escapar. Y entonces, de repente, escuchó un ruido. Un ruido que provenía de la ciudad que habían dejado atrás. Un ruido que sonaba como... como un lamento. Un lamento que se elevaba hacia el cielo, un lamento que parecía venir de todas partes y de ninguna parte al mismo tiempo. Montag se sintió como si su corazón se hubiera detenido. Se sintió como si estuviera viviendo en un infierno, un infierno que no tenía fin. Y entonces, de repente, todo se detuvo. El ruido cesó, y el silencio volvió a reinar. Montag se sintió como si estuviera solo en el mundo, como si fuera el único ser humano que quedaba. Y entonces, de repente, escuchó su propia voz. Una voz que parecía venir de muy lejos, una voz que decía: "¿Qué hemos hecho? ¿Qué hemos hecho?"

en_first_half: The men lay gasping like fish laid out on the grass. They held to the earth as children hold to familiar things, no matter how cold or dead, no matter what has happened or will happen, their fingers were clawed into the
en_second_half: dirt, and they were all shouting to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their sanity from bursting, mouths open, Montag shouting with them, a protest against the wind that ripped their faces and tore at their lips, making their noses bleed.
en_results: ground as if it were a lifeline, a tangible connection to a reality that seemed to be slipping away from them. The air was heavy with the smell of sweat and smoke, and the sound of distant gunfire still echoed in their ears. They had been running for
en_results_raw: ground as if it were a lifeline, a tangible connection to a reality that seemed to be slipping away from them. The air was heavy with the smell of sweat and smoke, and the sound of distant gunfire still echoed in their ears. They had been running for what felt like hours, their legs burning and their lungs heaving, but they knew they couldn't stop now. They had to keep moving, had to find a way to escape the chaos that had erupted around them. As they lay there, trying to catch their breath, they couldn't help but think of all the things that had led them to this moment. The decisions they had made, the paths they had chosen, the mistakes they had committed. It all seemed so clear now, so obvious, but at the time, it had been anything but. They had been blinded by their own fears and doubts, and now they were paying the price. But even as they lay there, feeling defeated and helpless, they knew they couldn't give up. They had to keep fighting, had to keep pushing forward, no matter what lay ahead. They slowly got to their feet, their legs shaking beneath them, and began to move forward, one step at a time, into the unknown.

La tierra parecía ser lo único que les quedaba, lo único que les daba una sensación de seguridad en un mundo que se había vuelto loco. Los hombres se aferraban a ella con desesperación, como si intentaran evitar que se los tragara, pero era inútil. La tierra los estaba tragando, poco a poco, y ellos lo sabían. en_results_raw: he felt his heart stumble and almost stop in his chest. The world around him seemed to slow down, and for a moment, the only sound was the soft rustling of the leaves and the quiet hum of the distant city. The girl's gaze held him transfixed, and he felt like he was drowning in the depths of her eyes, unable to look away or move. It was as if time itself had frozen, leaving only the two of them, suspended in a world of their own. The girl's eyes seemed to hold a deep wisdom, a knowing that went beyond her years, and Montag felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that she saw him, truly saw him, in a way that no one else ever had. And in that moment, he knew that his life would never be the same again.

en_results_raw: leaving behind a vacuum, a sense of emptiness that echoed through the deserted streets. But this time, something was different. The books, they seemed to be everywhere, a tidal wave of knowledge and ideas that threatened to engulf them. Montag stumbled, his foot catching on a stray volume, and as he fell, the words on the pages seemed to leap out at him, a jumbled mess of thoughts and emotions that he couldn't quite process. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that these books, these forbidden tomes, held a power that he had never truly understood. The police, with their sterile efficiency, had always made it seem so simple, so clinical, but now, as he waded through the sea of pages, Montag began to grasp the true nature of the destruction they had wrought. The books, they were not just words on paper, but a gateway to a world of ideas, of thoughts, of emotions, and it was this that the authorities feared most. As he struggled to his feet, Montag felt a sense of wonder, of awe, at the sheer magnitude of what he had stumbled upon. He knew that he had to get out, to escape the musty blackness, to find a way to preserve this knowledge, to keep it safe from those who would seek to destroy it. But for now, he simply stood there, surrounded by the books, feeling the weight of their words, and the power that they held.

en_results_raw: and the men's forced merriment only served to heighten the sense of unease that settled over the gathering like a shroud. The woman's presence was a stark reminder that their carefully constructed facade was fragile, that the secrets they kept hidden could be exposed at any moment. As the night wore on, the tension grew thicker, until it seemed to vibrate through every molecule of air, threatening to shatter the delicate balance of their charade. The men's laughter began to sound hollow, their jokes falling flat, as they struggled to maintain the illusion of normalcy in the face of her unyielding silence. And yet, despite the growing unease, no one dared to confront her, to ask the questions that hung in the air like a challenge. Instead, they averted their eyes, pretending not to notice the way she seemed to be watching them, her gaze piercing the veil of their deception. The ritual, once a comforting routine, had been transformed into a twisted game of cat and mouse, with the woman as the unpredictable wild card. As the hours ticked by, the men's anxiety reached a fever pitch, until it seemed that the very walls were closing in on them, suffocating them with the weight of their own guilt.

en_results_raw: of hardness that made them seem almost opaque, her skin pale and dry, like the surface of a long-dead leaf. She was a woman who had been drained of all vitality, all passion, all sense of purpose, and yet she stood there, watching him with an unblinking gaze, as if waiting for him to stir, to wake, to rise from the ashes of his own private hell. The air was heavy with the scent of decay and stagnation, the stench of a life gone sour, and Mildred's presence seemed to be the epicenter of it all, the source of the rot that had infected everything around her. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he lay there, sensing the weight of her gaze upon him, the crushing pressure of her expectations, her needs, her desires. And yet, he couldn't bring himself to open his eyes, to face her, to confront the reality of his own existence, the bleak and barren landscape that stretched out before him like a desert without end.

The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.

You're a throwback to a time when people actually felt deeply, when they actually thought for themselves. You're a relic of a bygone era, and that's what makes you so fascinating. But it's also what makes you so vulnerable. In a world that values instant gratification and superficiality, you're a threat. You're a reminder that there's more to life than just existing. You're a reminder that there's beauty and depth and meaning to be found, if only we take the time to look. And that's a very dangerous thing indeed.

No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.

Búsquelo en la vida misma, en su propia vida, en su propia alma. Porque allí es donde se encuentra la verdadera magia, la verdadera poesía, la verdadera música. No en los libros, no en las pantallas, no en las máquinas, sino en la experiencia humana, en la conexión con los demás, en la conexión con el mundo que nos rodea. Eso es lo que usted está buscando, amigo mío. Eso es lo que todos estamos buscando.

en_second_half: off and spilled out like swan-feathers, the incredible books that looked so silly and really not worth bothering with, for these were nothing but black type and yellowed paper, and ravelled binding.
en_results: and scattered, the books that had been the cause of all this chaos, their pages fluttering like wounded birds, their words, once full of meaning, now nothing more than scattered, meaningless scraps of
en_results_raw: and scattered, the books that had been the cause of all this chaos, their pages fluttering like wounded birds, their words, once full of meaning, now nothing more than scattered, meaningless scraps of paper. The room was heavy with the scent of smoke and ash, the acrid smell of destruction, and Montag's heart felt heavy with the weight of what he had done. He thought of Mildred, of her empty, vapid face, of her love of the parlour walls and the endless, mindless chatter of the seashell radios, and he felt a pang of sorrow, of regret for what he had lost, for what he had destroyed. He thought of Faber, of his wise, old eyes, of his gentle, guiding hand, and he felt a sense of gratitude, of hope. And he thought of the books, of their words, of their wisdom, and he knew that he had to keep them alive, to preserve them, to pass them on to a world that desperately needed them. He took a deep breath, and began to gather up the scattered pages, to collect the torn covers, to rebuild, to restart, to rediscover the knowledge, the wisdom, the beauty that had been lost.

Montag se sintió invadido por una sensación de vacío y desolación, como si el mundo que conocía se estuviera desmoronando a su alrededor. The two silver beetles were still there, their drivers chatting with the attendant as they filled up on gas. Montag's eyes lingered on the vehicles, wondering who these people were and what they wanted with him. He spotted a small café next to the gas station and decided to grab a cup of coffee while he waited. As he walked in, the aroma of freshly brewed coffee enveloped him, and he felt a sense of normalcy wash over him, a feeling he hadn't experienced in a long time. He took a seat at the counter, ordering a black coffee, and waited, his eyes fixed on the door, waiting for whoever it was that was supposed to meet him.

en_results_raw: master. The sound of his footsteps echoed off the cold, grey walls as he sprinted down the desolate corridor, his breath coming in ragged gasps. His eyes darted wildly about, as if searching for some escape from the desperation that drove him. The beetle, its shiny black carapace glinting in the dim light, scurried after him, a tiny, insignificant shadow. The man's cries grew louder, more anguished, until they were almost a scream, and still he ran, his long legs eating up the distance. And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, everything was silent. The man stopped running, his chest heaving, his eyes fixed on some point in front of him. The beetle, too, came to a halt, its antennae twitching uncertainly. In the stillness, the only sound was the man's labored breathing, and the soft, almost imperceptible hum of the beetle's wings.

The city, once a place of warmth and comfort, now seemed cold and unforgiving, its towering skyscrapers looming above him like specters. He felt small and insignificant, a tiny cog in a machine that was determined to crush him. And yet, he pressed on, driven by a spark within him that refused to be extinguished. The alley, a narrow passageway between two large buildings, was his only refuge, a place where he could catch his breath and gather his thoughts. But for how long? The authorities would be searching for him, and it was only a matter of time before they found him. Montag knew he had to keep moving, to find a way out of the city and into the unknown. en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”
en_results: another child in need. I realized that it wasn't the person I was mourning, but the absence of their actions, their presence, and their love in the world. My grandfather's legacy lived on through the toys he made, the lives he touched, and the lessons he taught. And I believe that's what we need to focus on now, not just the person we've lost, but the impact they had on us and the

And that's what I think is happening here. We're not just mourning the loss of a person, we're mourning the loss of what they brought to our lives, the memories we shared with them, and the impact they had on our community. My grandfather's legacy lived on through the toys he made, the lives he touched, and the lessons he taught. And I believe that's what we need to focus on now, not just the person we've lost, but the impact they had on us and the world around us. We need to keep their memory alive by continuing their work, by spreading their love and kindness, and by making sure their legacy lives on. That's how we can truly honor their memory and keep them alive in our hearts. As we move forward, let's not forget the lessons they taught us, the laughter we shared, and the memories we created together. Let's keep their spirit alive by being the change we want to see in the world, by being the love and kindness they embodied. That's how we can make sure their passing is not in vain, but a catalyst for us to become better versions of ourselves and to make the world a better place.

es_first_half: —Escuche —dijo Granger, cogiéndole por un brazo y andando a su lado, mientras apartaba los arbustos para dejarle pasar—. Cuando era niño, mi abuelo murió. Era escultor. También era un hombre muy bueno, tenía mucho amor que dar al mundo, y ayudó a eliminar la miseria en nuestra ciudad; y construía juguetes para nosotros, y se dedicó a mil actividades durante su vida; siempre tenía las manos ocupadas. Y cuando murió, de pronto me di cuenta de que no lloraba por él, sino por las cosas que hacía. Lloraba porque nunca más volvería hacerlas, nunca más volvería a labrar otro pedazo de madera y no nos
es_second_half: ayudaría a criar pichones en el patio ni tocaría el violín como él sabía hacerlo, ni nos contaría chistes. Formaba parte de nosotros, y cuando murió todas las actividades se interrumpieron, y nadie era capaz de hacerlas como él. Era individualista. Era un hombre importante. Nunca me he sobrepuesto a su muerte. A menudo, pienso en las tallas maravillosas que nunca han cobrado forma a causa de su muerte. Cuántos chistes faltan al mundo, y cuántos pichones no sido tocados por sus manos. Configuró el mundo, hizo cosas en su beneficio. La noche en que falleció, el mundo sufrió una pérdida de diez millones de buenas acciones.

Porque sé que, aunque la vida sea dura y cruel a veces, siempre hay algo que nos hace sonreír, algo que nos hace recordar que la vida es hermosa, que la vida es un regalo. As I grew older, my interest in rocketry only deepened, and I began to study the subject in earnest, pouring over books and documentaries, and even building my own model rockets. The men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything, for the whole thing had happened in the blink of an eye, in the time it takes for a man to draw a breath, to feel his heart beat once, twice, and then the world was changed forever. The city, the buildings, the streets, the people, all were gone, consumed by a fire that seemed to have no end, a fire that raged and roared and devoured everything in its path. The men stood there, frozen in shock, unable to move, unable to speak, unable to comprehend the magnitude of what they had just witnessed. The world around them was in ruins, and they were left to pick up the pieces, to try to make sense of the senseless, to try to find some semblance of order in the chaos that had been unleashed upon the world. And in the midst of all this destruction, Montag stood, his eyes fixed on the horizon, his heart heavy with the knowledge of what he had seen, his mind reeling with the implications of what had happened. He knew that nothing would ever be the same again, that the world had been forever changed by the events of this day. And he knew that he would never be able to go back to the way things were before, that he would never be able to forget what he had seen, what he had witnessed. The memory of this day would haunt him forever, a constant reminder of the destructive power of human ingenuity, of the devastating consequences of unchecked technological advancement. And as he stood there, lost in thought, the world around him began to stir, to come back to life, to pick up the pieces and try to move on. But Montag knew that he would never be able to move on, that he would always be haunted by the memories of this day, of the day the world ended.

en_results_raw: ground as if it were a lifeline, a tangible connection to a reality that seemed to be slipping away from them. The air was heavy with the smell of sweat and smoke, and the only sound was the labored breathing of the men, their chests heaving like bellows as they struggled to catch their breath. The earth beneath them was cool and damp, a welcome respite from the heat of the battle that had raged on for what seemed like hours. As they lay there, they couldn't help but think of the events that had led them to this moment, the choices they had made, the sacrifices they had endured, and the losses they had suffered. The weight of it all bore down on them, crushing them beneath its oppressive yoke, making it hard to breathe, hard to think, hard to remember why they were fighting in the first place. And yet, even as they lay there, defeated and demoralized, they knew they couldn't give up, not yet, not when there was still a glimmer of hope, no matter how small, no matter how faint.

But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
